Graphical abstract An efficient C3H8–SCR catalyst with remarkable surface acidity, high surface area and high hydrothermal stability has been developed using an innovative catalyst preparation technique. In this method, a combination of direct and post-synthesis methods (DS–PS) has been employed sequentially for the preparation of a highly Zr-loaded SBA-15 (32.1wt%). A series of novel catalysts have been developed by doping various contents of nickel on the prepared Zr-loaded support and have been used for NO reduction with propane in the presence of excess oxygen and water vapor in a fixed bed reactor. Among the various catalysts prepared, the catalyst with a nickel content of 2.5wt% exhibited the highest activity with the ability to fully convert NO into N2 in the presence of 10% oxygen, 1750ppm propane and 500ppm NO at 450°C. A satisfactory catalytic activity has been found in the presence of 7vol% of water vapor. Keywords Catalyst NOx reduction Zr-SBA-15 C3H8–SCR Direct–post synthesis method 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are produced during combustion in an internal combustion engine at high temperature. NOx has been considered as one of the major air pollutants. This pollutant can cause various environmental pollutions such as photochemical smog formation, acid rain production and ozone depletion [1]. Therefore attempt is done to reduce the emission of this harmful gas to the environment. One of the methods that can significantly reduce NOx emission is the use of an after-treatment system equipped with various catalysts. Amongst, the conventional tree-way catalytic system has shown to be able to reduce NOx significantly [2]. However, this catalyst is not effective in the exhaust of lean-burn engines because CO and unburned hydrocarbons necessary for NO reduction are oxidized by large amount of oxygen existing in the lean-burn exhaust. To overcome this problem, selective catalytic reduction of NOx with hydrocarbons (HC–SCR) has been as an attractive solution due to its simplicity [3] and availability of the unburned hydrocarbons in the lean-burn exhaust [4]. Zeolite-based catalytic systems such as Ni, Pt and Pd supported on ZSM-5, FER, MOR and BEA as well as CuZSM-5, FeZSM-5, CoZSM-5 have been studied for hydrocarbon reduction of NOx extensively [5–8]. These catalysts have shown promising results in the absence of water vapor and SO2. However, the activity of catalysts decreased drastically in the presence of water vapor due to instability in the structure in hydrothermal condition [6,9]. Metal oxide-based catalytic systems such as Al2O3 and ZrO2 have been found to be effective for the reduction of NO with hydrocarbons. Moreover, they have shown higher hydrothermal stability than zeolite-based catalysts [6,10–13]. The catalytic activity of Ni–ZrO2 for the reduction of NO with propane has been investigated by Bethke et al. [11]. NO conversion of 32.7% over Ni (7.6wt%)–ZrO2 at 637K and 27.9% over Ni (6.7wt%)–ZrO2 at 693K were achieved. In another study, ZrO2 as a sole catalyst exhibited about 30% NO conversion at 550°C [14]. Low surface area and porosity were the major disadvantages of this catalytic system which might lead to low activity [11,15–17]. Different approaches such as mesoporous ZrO2 preparation and combination of Zr species with mesoporous silica-based material have been applied to increase the surface area [15,16,18]. Amongst, modification of SBA-15 with zirconium atoms provides several important properties which are necessary for NOx reduction such as high surface area, appropriate acidity, strong metal-support interaction and satisfactory hydrothermal stability [13,19–21]. The activity of Pt loaded on Al-SBA-15 for the reduction NO with C3H6 has been studied so far [22]. However, application of transition metal such as Ni supported on Zr-SBA-15 for NO reduction with propane has been barely noticed. Hence, the aim of this study has been devoted to, first, develop Zr-SBA-15 with high concentration of Zr by means of an innovative method while maintaining the well-ordered structure of the pristine SBA-15. Second, investigation of the performance of Ni catalysts supported on developed Zr-SBA-15. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of Zr-SBA-15 by direct synthesis For the preparation of Zr-SBA-15 by direct method, the method reported by Gracia et al. [23] was applied with some modification. ZrONO3·xH2O was used as the Zr precursor. 2.5g of a pluronic triblock copolymer P123 was dissolved in 93.75ml of 0.03M hydrochloric acid solution at 35°C. Then, 5.625ml TEOS with an appropriate amount of zirconium precursor, according to the desired Si/Zr ratio (Si/Zr=10 and 5) in the initial gel, was added to the solution. The resulting mixture was stirred for 24h at 35°C prior to hydrothermal treatment at 100°C for 24h under autogenous pressure. The final product was filtrated, washed several times with deionized water, dried at 60°C overnight and calcined at 600°C for 8h. The prepared materials are denoted as Zr-SBA (DS) and Zr-SBA (DSH) for Si/Zr=10 and 5, respectively. 2.2 Preparation of Zr-SBA-15 by post synthesis Chemical grafting was applied for post synthesis. Zirconium(IV) propoxide [Zr(n-PrO)4] (70wt% solution in 1-propanol) and absolute ethanol were used as the zirconium source and solvent, respectively [24]. However, the developed method was based on using absolute ethanol rather than dry one reported by Gutiérrez et al. [24]. Appropriate amounts of prepared SBA-15 [25] and zirconium precursor were mixed in the absolute ethanol overnight at room temperature under nitrogen stream. A solid to liquid ratio (S/L) value of 0.06 was used. The product was filtered and washed with absolute ethanol three times to eliminate excess Zr(n-PrO)4. The solid was then dried at room temperature under nitrogen stream overnight prior to calcination at 550oC for 5.5h. The prepared material is called Zr-SBA (PS). 2.3 Preparation of support by combined direct and post synthesis The procedure of this novel method is the same as post-synthesis method. To begin with, Zr-SBA (DS) was prepared using the procedure explained above and then the produced material was used as a precursor in the post-synthesis method instead of SBA-15. The final material is called Zr-SBA (DS–PS), where DS–PS stands for direct and post synthesis sequentially. 2.4 Synthesis of catalyst A series of Ni catalysts supported on Zr-SBA (DS), Zr-SBA (PS) and Zr-SBA (DS–PS) were prepared by initial wetness impregnation. An appropriate volume of the solution of Ni (NO3)·6H2O was impregnated into the support to achieve a desired content of Ni (15, 10, 5 and 2.5wt%). The impregnated product was dried overnight at 70°C, followed by calcination at 500°C for 5h. The catalysts were termed as Zr-SBA (DS, PS and DS–PS)-X, where X represents the Ni content in the catalyst. 2.5 Materials characterization The supports and catalysts were characterized by means of several methods as described below. 2.5.1 Crystallinity The crystallinity of the prepared supports and catalysts was evaluated by X-ray diffraction (XRD). A Philips PW1825 diffractometer at a wavelength of 1.54Å of CuKα radiation was used to obtain the spectra. Different angular ranges at a speed of 0.025°s−1 and a step of 0.05° were applied for sample scanning. The operation conditions of equipment were adjusted to 40kV and 50mA. A finely ground sample (0.05g) was used for each analysis. Furthermore, the low angle X-ray diffraction of the sample was performed on a PANalytical X’pert Pro powder X-ray diffractometer with a scanning range of 0.5 to 3° 2θ in steps of 0.02° 2θ per second with an acquisition time of 5s per step. 2.5.2 X-ray fluorescence (XRF) X-ray fluorescence (XRF) was used to determine the bulk metal content of the support and catalyst. A 30kV electron voltage and 0–3mA for the current of the X-ray source was adjusted for the experiments. 2.5.3 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption A coulter SA3100 surface area analyzer was used to conduct physical adsorption measurements with N2 at 77K. The specific surface area and pore volume of the support and catalyst were calculated by measuring the amount of nitrogen adsorbed and desorbed from the sample at different pressures. The specific surface area was calculated from the nitrogen adsorption data in the relative pressure range of 0.05 to 0.2 using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. The total pore volume was calculated at the relative pressure of 0.98. 2.5.4 Morphological study by TEM-EDX The general morphology of the supports and catalysts was examined by transmission electron microscopy assisted with energy dispersive X-ray (TEM-EDX). TEM samples were prepared by dispersing 0.05g of the powder sample in an absolute ethanol solution, followed by ultrasonic treatment for 30min. A few drops of the prepared solution were then added onto a carbon-covered grid (60mesh), followed by drying in an oven at 70°C. TEM experiments were performed on the JEOL 2010F TEM unit at 200kV. The EDX technique was used to determine the metal concentration of the samples. 2.5.5 Surface composition spectroscopy Surface chemistry of the sample including the elemental composition, concentrations and chemical states were obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS-PHI5600), in which an X-ray at the power of 150W was produced by a monochromatic Al source. Low resolution spectrum for the whole range was acquired at 160eV pass energy, whereas high resolution narrow range spectra for elements of interest were acquired at 20eV pass energy. The spectra were corrected by C (1s) at 284.6eV as reference. 2.5.6 Surface acidity A pulse chromatographic technique of gas-phase at 300°C was used to measure the surface acidity. Total acidity (Brönsted and Lewis acid sites) and Brönsted site were determined by pyridine (PY) and 2,6-dimethylpyridine (DMPY) as probe molecules, respectively [26]. 2.6 Catalyst performance evaluation The catalytic activity was evaluated by a bespoke stainless steel circular reactor fed by a simulated lean burn exhaust gas. The feed gases (all of high purity of >99.99%) were nitric oxide (500ppm), propane (500–2000ppm), oxygen (6–10vol%), water vapor (0–7vol%) and helium. The steady state conditions were considered to determine the catalyst performance. The effluent gases were analyzed by a gas chromatograph with TCD detector to detect N2, N2O and CO2. Typically, 0.5g of the catalyst was loaded into the reaction tube. The reactor was then connected to the feeding and analysis sections. The gas flow rate was fixed at 100mlmin−1. The effects of various parameters such as catalyst compositions, reaction temperature and concentration of propane, oxygen and water vapor were examined. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Zr content of the support The chemical compositions of the supports prepared by various methods are shown in Table 1 . Comparing the compositions of these supports suggests a significant enhancement in the Zr content when a combination of direct- and post-synthesis methods (DS–PS) is employed. The Zr content of the support considerably increases from 5.1wt% in Zr-SBA (DS) and 16.7wt% in Zr-SBA (PS) to 32.1wt% in Zr-SBA (DS–PS). In the direct synthesis method, the SBA-15 structure was preserved intact when the Si/Zr ratio was regulated at 10 or higher. Higher Zr contents (Zr-SBA (DSH)), lead to a collapse in SBA-15 structure (Fig. 1a), resulting in a drastic decrease in the specific surface area of the support, which is an essential factor for catalytic reactions. This structural collapse at high Zr loadings has been attributed to the limitation incurred by the SBA-15 structure to accommodate guest metals if the original structure of the SBA-15 is to remain intact [27]. Hence, a maximum Zr contribution of 5.1wt% into the SBA-15 framework was achieved in the direct synthesis method in this study. These results are in good agreement with the literature [27]. In the case of post-synthesis, a higher Zr content of 16.7wt% compared with the direct synthesis method was achieved by keeping the 2-D hexagonal structure of SBA-15 intact (Fig. 1a). Gutiérrez et al. [28] observed that the contribution of Zr within the SBA-15 framework could not be unlimited and a saturation level of 23.4wt% Zr deposition was achieved by this method. In this study, the highest deposition level of the Zr on the SBA-15 (16.7wt%) is lower than the saturation level suggested by Gutiérrez et al. It can be due to the type of solvent used. In this study, post synthesis was carried out in the presence of absolute ethanol (99.5%) whereas dry ethanol (99.999%) was used by Gutiérrez et al. [29]. It is believed that there should be a trade-off between the cost of the solvent and the catalytic activity. Due to the high cost of dry ethanol, it seems reasonable to slightly sacrifice the Zr content of the support for a considerably lower cost. Using the novel method, i.e., combination of direct and post-synthesis methods sequentially, for Zr-SBA-15 preparation, a remarkably high content of Zr (32.1wt%) in the SBA-15 framework was achieved while the mesoporous structure of SBA-15 was preserved without any considerable collapse. The XRD pattern of prepared Zr-SBA (DS–PS) (Fig. 1a) validates the integrity of the SBA-15 structure. The high Zr content in this new method might be explained as follows. Direct synthesis method results in the formation of Lewis and Brönsted acid sites [30] as a result of Zr incorporation into the SBA-15 frameworks. The subsequent post synthesis of the Zr-loaded support leads to the reaction between the acid sites of Zr-SBA (DS) and zirconium precursor used in the post-synthesis method (Zr(n-PrO)4), which can, consequently, cause more Zr deposition on the prepared support material (Zr-SBA (DS–PS)). 3.2 Low and high angle X-ray patterns of the support Low- and high-angle X-ray diffraction patterns of the various supports and the catalyst with the highest nickel content (Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-15) are illustrated in Fig. 1a and b. Zr-SBA (DS) and Zr-SBA (PS) exhibit three well-resolved peaks (Fig. 1a), indicative of SBA-15 crystallinity, which demonstrates that the 2-D hexagonal structure has remained intact in both cases throughout the synthesis process [15]. However, the intensity of the crystallinity peaks in Zr-SBA (PS) decreases in comparison to the parent SBA-15. This shows that a small modification of the long-range order of the pores of SBA-15 has occurred due to Zr loading [24]. Also, Fig. 1a shows that the new method retains the crystal structure of Zr-SBA (DS–PS), similar to the other methods. It is indicative of the proper dispersion of the Zr species throughout SBA-15 structure without any significant collapse in the crystal structure. Low-angle XRD pattern of the catalyst (Fig. 1a) showed the mesoporous structure of the support remained intact after Ni loading and therefore prepared catalyst can gain the advantages of mesoporous structure during the reaction. The non-collapsed crystalline structure of the prepared supports and catalyst materials is further verified by high-angel X-ray diffraction results, depicted in Fig. 1b. No diffraction signal related to the presence of crystalline zirconium dioxide phase is detected in these materials, even for the remarkably high content of zirconium in Zr-SBA (DS–PS). This verifies the lack of agglomeration of zirconium oxide species either in the framework or on the surface of the SBA-15. Moreover, no aggregated Ni oxide were also detected in high-angle X-ray patterns of the catalyst. 3.3 Nitrogen adsorption/desorption The specific surface areas of the prepared supports and catalysts have been presented in Table 2 . It has been found that Zr incorporation in the SBA-15 framework results in a decrease in the surface areas of the supports. This can be due to a slight structural modification of the SBA-15 structure, confirming the XRD results. This has also been observed by several other researchers [23,27]. Also, the total pore volume of the prepared supports by direct, post and direct–post synthesis techniques showed a decreasing trend of 1.18, 0.88 and 0.70cm3 g−1, respectively, which is consistent with the relevant literature [24]. This clearly shows that as the Zr-loading increases, slight long-range order modification of the SBA-15 takes place, as expected. An additional decrease in the surface areas of the prepared catalysts occurs after the nickel-loading of the support. As the nickel contents of the catalysts increase, more pronounced structural modification takes place, resulting in lower surface areas of the catalysts. When the Ni contents of the catalysts increase from 2.5wt% to 15wt%, the surface areas decrease from 473 to 351m2 g−1. This is ascribed to the dispersion of Ni species onto the internal and/or external surfaces of the supports. Furthermore, the calcination at high temperature (500°C) does not lead to a significant change in the catalyst surface area which is a required property for NOx reduction catalysts because higher surface areas provide more active sites for the chemisorption of the reactants [31]. 3.4 Transmission electron microscopy assisted with energy dispersive X-ray (TEM-EDX) TEM images of Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5 and 15 are shown in Fig. 2 . This Figure clearly shows the hexagonal network structure of the catalysts with cylindrical pores. It implies that the nickel-loading of the support does not lead to the collapse of the hexagonal morphology and presents a uniform and long-ordered structure. The distribution of the Zr and Ni metals in the catalyst framework is further confirmed by energy-dispersive X-ray analysis (EDX), as can be seen in Table 3 for two distinct regions (points A and B in Fig. 2a) of the Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5. 3.5 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Fig. 3a–c depict the XPS spectra of the support (Zr-SBA (DS–PS) and catalysts (Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5 and SBA-15-Ni-5). According to the literature [32–35], the binding energy of Zr core line 3d5/2 for ZrO2 as bulk oxide is about 182.4eV. However, a much higher binding energy of Zr 3d5/2 (183.4eV) (Fig. 3a) was achieved on Zr-SBA (DS–PS), suggesting the presence of Zr species in the structure were other than bulk ZrO2. Tang et al. [33] has attributed the higher binding energy of Zr 3d5/2 in Zr-SBA-15 to the formation of SiOZr bond due to the higher electronegativity of Si atom as compared to Zr atom. This is further confirmed by considering the Zr core line 3d3/2. The binding energy of Zr3d3/2 (186eV) was observed on Zr-SBA (DS–PS) which was higher than the binding energy assigned to ZrO2 in oxide form (185.3eV) [36]. These results demonstrate that the introduced Zr species to the SBA-15 structure could be as substituted Zr atoms in the framework, surface SiOZr linkage and ZrOH moieties. Moreover, the formation of covalent ZrOZr linkage could also be resulted by the reaction of Zr (OC3H7)4 and surface ZrOH groups during Zr-SBA (DS–PS) preparation [33]. XPS spectra of the Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5 catalyst (Fig. 3a) showed that the binding energy of Zr core line 3d5/2 was found to be 183.1eV. It implies that Ni loading on the support resulted in a very slight decrease in binding energy of Zr3d5/2 which can be attributed to the potential charge transfer from the Ni to Zr and Si. This charge transfer could slightly increase the electron cloud on the Zr which, in turn, decreases the binding energy of Zr3d5/2. This conclusion was further confirmed by XPS results of NiO species. The binding energy of Ni core line 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5 (Fig. 3b) were detected to be 856 and 873eV, respectively. SBA-15-Ni-5 without zirconium, exhibited a slight decrease in binding energies of 2p3/2 (855.7eV) and 2p1/2 (872.6eV). Ni 2p3/2 binding energy of both materials is about 3eV higher than that of NiO (853eV) but is similar to that of NiSiO3 (856.1eV) [37,38], implying strong interaction of NiO with support. Moreover, it demonstrates that Ni species were not affected by the Zr species significantly. The deconvolution of the oxygen spectrum (Fig. 3c) exhibits three distinct peaks centered at 533.1, 532.5, and 531.0eV. The two peaks at higher bonding energies (533.1 and 532.5eV) are ascribed to the bridging oxygen atoms in the support framework as SiOSi and SiOZr, while the oxygen peak at 531.0eV demonstrates the presence of non-bridging oxygen atoms attached to either Si or Zr atoms. The presence of these peaks further confirms the proper modification of SBA-15 network structure, rather than the presence of aggregated ZrO2 mixed with the SiO2, as O1s spectra of the bulk ZrO2 are in the range of 529.1–530eV [32]. 3.6 Surface acidity Surface acidity results are summarized in Table 4 . Notably, it is well-documented that SBA-15 has no significant acidity [33,39,40] and thus it has not been included in this Table 4. Both supports and catalysts possess Brönsted and Lewis acid sites, essential for HC–SCR [13]. The surface acidity results indicate that the quantity of Lewis acid sites has increased from 29 and 32μmol/g for the supports synthesized by the direct and post-synthesis methods, respectively, to 37μmol/g for the support synthesized by the new technique applied in this study. According to Table 4, the amounts of Lewis and Brönsted acids are directly proportional to the quantity of Zr in the support, where Zr-SBA (DS–PS) with the highest content of Zr has shown the highest amount of acidity [27,30]. The acidity of the catalysts does not change significantly after Ni loading of the support. Lewis and Brönsted acidity slightly decreases from 36 to 31μmol/g and from 94 to 89μmol/g, respectively, when Ni content increases from 2.5 to 5wt%. It has already been reported that SCR activity of the catalysts are directly proportional to the extent of the Lewis and Brönsted acid sites [41]. This is because nitrate and nitrite anions act as intermediate species to be chemisorbed on the Lewis acid sites. The interaction of the ions and acid sites leads to the formation of the coordination complexes [42]. Subsequently, the reaction between adsorbed NO3 − species with the oxygenated hydrocarbons results in the conversion of NOx into nitrogen in the HC–SCR reaction [41]. Hence, HC oxidation and NOx conversion highly depend on the availability, density and strength of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites [43,44]. Due to the high acidity of the prepared nickel-doped catalysts, it is expected that these materials have a high potential to be used as active catalysts in HC–SCR reaction. 3.7 Catalytic activity In order to evaluate the catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts, reaction conditions such as the effect of temperature, reducing agent and oxygen concentration have been investigated. Moreover, the effect of the catalyst compositions, i.e., Ni and Zr content, has been examined. 3.7.1 Effect of Ni content Fig. 4 shows the catalytic activities of catalysts with various Ni contents. NO conversion to N2 has been considered as the catalyst performance and has been calculated as follows: Conversion of NO to N 2 = 2 × N 2 out NO in × 100 where [N2]out and [NO]in represent the moles of N2 in the outlet and NO in the feed stream, respectively. Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-10 shows a better performance compared to Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-15 in the studied temperature range. At extreme temperatures, the NO conversion decreased from 36% and 40% to 21% and 22% at 400 and 450°C, respectively. The considerable difference between the performances of these two catalysts cannot be assigned to their specific surface areas as the BET specific surface areas of these two catalysts are in the same range (Table 2). This phenomenon can be explained by two competing reactions: oxidation of propane and conversion of propane to intermediate species favorable for NO reduction. When the Ni concentration on the catalyst surface is very high (15wt%), the former reaction is dominant and thus less intermediate species are produced to react with the NO intermediate species, while a catalyst with a lower nickel content favors the latter reaction [45]. This hypothesis can be further verified by the production of a higher CO2 amount (the results are not shown) when Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-15 was used as catalyst compared with Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-10. When the nickel content further decreases from 10wt% to 5wt%, Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5 exhibited lower activity at lower temperatures (250–350°C). This is attributed to the deposition of carbonaceous species on the active sites at low temperatures which may lead to a higher degree of catalyst deactivation, whereas higher loading of nickel suppresses the formation of carbonaceous species at such low temperatures, resulting in higher catalytic activity for NO reduction [5]. At a temperature of 450°C, lower concentration of the nickel leads to NO reduction rather than propane oxidation. Similar trend is observed when the catalysts with nickel contents of 2.5wt% and 5wt% were used. Shi et al. [45] have reported the same trend for Ag–Al2O3 catalyst at different temperatures. 3.7.2 Effect of Zr content The effect of Zr content on NO reduction was evaluated using a constant Ni content of 5wt% doped onto Zr-SBA (DS), Zr-SBA (PS), Zr-SBA (DS–PS) and SBA-15. As depicted in Fig. 5 , the activity of the catalysts is considerably affected by Zr content; Zr-SBA (DS–PS) with the highest Zr loading exhibited the highest NO conversion to N2 at all temperatures whereas SBA-15-Ni-5 showed the lowest N2 yield. This phenomenon is consistent with the density of the surface acidity, which is in order of Zr-SBA (DS–PS)>Zr-SBA (PS)>Zr-SBA (DS) (Table 4). Anderson et al.[46] have reported the effect of zirconium content of the catalysts on their surface acidity. It has been shown that higher zirconium content increases the number of protonic sites of catalysts, which, in turn, enhances the Brönsted acid behavior of their surface. In addition, Lewis acidity originated from the vacant orbitals in the zirconium molecular structure considerably enhances the surface acidity of catalysts. Therefore, an increase in the content of zirconium amount in the structure of the catalyst induces the formation of more acid surface sites. According to Miller et al. [47], as the NO reduction occurs at the acidic sites rather than at the metal ion sites, an increase in the number of the acidic sites promotes the formation of the NOx ad-species and thus increases the overall conversion of NO to N2. The role of nickel and zirconium active sites can be elucidated if the reaction pathway in HC–SCR is considered. It has been well acknowledged that the conversion of NO to N2 occurs via several sequential reactions in HC–SCR. The first step is the formation of the intermediate oxygenated hydrocarbon species (C x H y O z ), which may follow two well-known pathways: (I) HC can be chemisorbed on Ni active sites through the dehydrogenation reaction and interact with the adsorbed oxygen atom which is the product of the dissociative adsorption of NO and/or O2 over Ni active sites, and (II) the adsorbed HC can interact with NOx ad-species bonded with Lewis acid sites. The second step involves the reaction between the C x H y O z formed in the first step and NOx ad-species which results in the formation of isocyanate species (NCO). Finally, the formation of N2 stems from the hydrolysis of the isocyanate compounds or its interaction with gaseous NO2 [63,64]. When Zr-SBA (DS–PS) was used as a catalyst, no CO2 (the results are not shown) or N2 (Fig. 4) was detected at 350°C. This signifies that in the absence of nickel, the first above-mentioned reaction step does not occur and thus it is concluded that the acidity of the catalyst is not the only parameter for NOx reduction and propane oxidation. On the other hand, SBA-15-Ni-5 as a catalyst results in the production of both CO2 (the results are not shown) and N2 gases (Fig. 5, at 350°C) showing that the conversion of NO to the desired products follows the two pathways introduced. However, the N2 yield is very low when no zirconium is incorporated into the catalyst structure. The introduction of Zr active sites into the catalyst highly enhances the NO to N2 conversion, implying the significance of the acid sites in the production of NOx ad-species, which has a direct relationship with N2 yield. 3.7.3 Effect of propane concentration Effect of propane concentration on NO reduction has been illustrated in Fig. 6 . When propane concentration increases from 500ppm to 1750ppm, N2 yield rises from 46% to 94% and from 47% to 100% for Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5 and Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-2.5, respectively. The reaction mechanism suggests that propane is converted to intermediate oxygenated hydrocarbons via several sequential reactions. Since the formation of these species, essential for the reduction of NO to N2, is the rate limiting step, higher concentration of the reducing agent in the feed stream results in the acceleration of the intermediate species formation and thereby enhances the conversion rate of NO to the nitrogen. Moreover, higher concentrations of propane increase the probability of the nickel site reduction through hydrocarbon dehydrogenation [1]. The activity of the catalysts showed that complete NO conversion by Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5 could be achieved at a higher propane concentration (2000ppm) compared to Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-2.5 (1750ppm). This might be related to the fact that as the nickel content of the catalyst increases, nickel clusters are formed rather than uniform dispersion of the nickel oxide. These clusters lead to the blockage of the catalyst pores and reduce the accessible active acid sites present in the interior parts of the pores, thus decreasing the acidity of the catalyst. These results are verified by the decrease in both the surface area (Table 2) and the surface acidity (Table 4) of the catalysts as the nickel loading increases. Similar trend in the textural property and surface acidity has been observed by increasing the metal contents of the modified ZSM-5 catalysts [48]. Moreover, dispersion of active metals on the catalyst surface can affect two main reaction pathways: (I) NO reduction, and (II) propane oxidation. Uniform dispersion of the metal oxides due to low metal content enhances the former reaction resulting in higher N2 yield, whereas high metal content brings about the formation of metal clusters which favor the latter reaction [45]. This phenomenon accounts for the hypothesis that high nickel loading of catalysts does not imply high catalyst activity, and therefore, an optimization of the metal content on the catalyst surface is required. 3.7.4 Effects of O2 concentration Oxygen content in the lean-burn catalytic reduction reaction is one of the key parameters to be investigated. To evaluate the catalytic performance of the Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-2.5 and Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5 in real lean-burn exhaust conditions, NO reduction reaction was carried out at various concentrations of oxygen, as shown in Fig. 7 . In the absence of oxygen, the catalysts do not exhibit any NO reduction. It can be because the reaction pathways in HC–SCR, i.e., formation of NOx ad-species through the oxidation of NO to NO2 and the formation of oxygenated hydrocarbon species [1,49], can only proceed in the presence of adequate concentrations of O2. According to Ueda et al. [50], the conversion of NO2 into nitrogen can occur even in the absence of oxygen. Therefore, it can be concluded that the lack of the formation of NO2 in the absence of oxygen might be the main reason to hinder the NO oxidation. On the other hand, some research in the literature has reported a decrease in NO conversion at oxygen concentrations above a certain threshold. For instance, Lou et al. [51] have shown that the catalyst activity for NO conversion has been considerably reduced when the oxygen concentrations increases from 2vol% to 8vol%. However, the prepared catalysts in this study showed that the conversion of NO to N2 for both catalysts was not significantly affected by increasing the oxygen concentration to 10vol%, which is known to be the oxygen content in a lean-burn engine exhaust [6]. This confirms the high tolerance of these catalysts to the more severe conditions in car exhaust. 3.7.5 Effect of water vapor on NO reduction over Zr-SBA (PS–DS)-Ni-5 Evaluation of the catalyst performance in the presence of water vapor is critical for the catalytic systems in HC–SCR because water vapor generated in the course of SCR reaction and propane combustion can influence the NO reduction in engine exhausts [52]. Since Zr-SBA (DS–PS)-Ni-5 showed a promising performance at both low and high temperatures, we decided to further examine the effect of water vapor on NO conversion. Fig. 8 shows the conversion of NO to N2 as a function of temperature and in the presence of 7vol% of water vapor, as a typical value for a lean-burn engine exhaust [1]. It was observed that although the nitrogen yield decreases from 47% in ideal conditions to 29% in the presence of water vapor at 450°C, the NO conversion to N2 is still in an acceptable range compared with other findings in the literature. Miyadera et al. have found that the NO conversion over alumina-supported gallium drastically decreased from 98% in the absence of water to 20% in the presence of 10vol% water vapor at 450°C [53]. Similar observations have been made by other researchers [54–57]. The reduction in the catalyst performance can be attributed to the competition between the reactants and water vapor molecules to be chemisorbed on the catalyst which can poison its Lewis acid sites into inactive sites [58]. In the case of the catalyst prepared by DS–PS method, the abundance of zirconium, as Lewis acid site, leads to lower deactivation of the catalyst. Therefore, the contribution of the novel DS–PS method, resulting in higher zirconium loading, can be more pronounced in real applications. 3.7.6 Influence of space velocity on NO reduction over Zr-SBA (PS–DS)-Ni-5 The effect of gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) on the catalyst activity was studied using various flow rates including 75, 100, 150 and 200mlmin−1. Fig. 9 demonstrates that NO conversion was affected by changing the gas space velocity. NO conversion increased from 47% to 51% when the flow rate was decreased from 100 to 75mlmin−1 at 450°C. However, at this temperature, 13% and 15% depletion in NO conversion was observed when the flow rate increased from 100 to 150mlmin−1 and 150 to 200mlmin−1, respectively. This observation was in good agreement with the results reported by Habib et al. [1], Kögel et al. [59] and Ruiz-Martínez et al. [60]. The phenomenon could be attributed to the decrease in residence time of the reactants in the catalyst bed. 3.7.7 Hydrothermal and long-term stability of the catalyst in dry and wet feed The hydrothermal and long-term stability of the Zr-SBA (PS–DS)-Ni-5 catalyst was investigated at higher temperature (550°C) for 24h and continued for another 36h at 450°C in the presence of water vapor (Fig. 10 ). At 550°C, the catalyst exhibited about 10% NO conversion and when temperature was decreased to 450°C, it retained its performance at 27% NO conversion for prolonged experiment. The low activity of the catalyst at high temperature can be explained by the fact that at high temperature, the direct oxidation of propane is favored. Therefore, small portion of propane can take part in the selective reduction of NO resulting in lower catalytic activity. Moreover, retainment of catalyst activity at 450°C indicates that the Zr-SBA (PS–DS)-Ni-5 possesses an acceptable hydrothermal stability. In addition, the results also showed that Ni species are chemically bonded to the catalyst structure and are not washed out easily from the catalyst surface by water vapor. This conclusion was further confirmed by XPS data of Ni core line 2p3/2 presenting strong interaction of NiO particles with the support (Fig. 3b). Since this catalyst has exhibited promising NO removal at severe conditions of high water vapor and oxygen concentrations as well as stability at hydrothermal conditions, it is plausible to utilize this catalyst in real car exhausts for NO removal. The comparison of this catalyst with well-developed noble metal-based catalysts can also highlight its high catalytic performance. Fuentes et al. [61] showed that less than 10% NOx conversion can be achieved by 2wt% Ag–γ-Al2O3 in the presence of 200ppm NO, 437ppm C3H8, 3% O2 and 6%H2O at 400°C. Inaba et al. [62] reported a N2 yield of 20% over a 0.5wt% Pt–Al2O3 catalyst in water vapor-free feed stream comprised of 1000ppm NO, 1000ppm C3H8 and 10vol% O2 at a temperature range of 350–400°C. The Zr-SBA (PS–DS)-Ni-5 catalyst prepared in the present study shows higher activity than 2wt% Ag–γ-Al2O3 and 0.5wt% Pt–Al2O3 at temperatures below 400°C and in more severe reaction conditions. Also, the cost effectiveness of the catalyst prepared by DS–PS method compared with that of the noble metal-based catalysts adds further incentives for their large-scale utilization. 4 Conclusion A new method was developed to prepare a highly active catalyst for the reduction of NO to N2 in the lean-burn condition. The preparation method was based on the combination of direct and post-synthesis techniques which resulted in the incorporation of a remarkably high Zr content in the support structure compared to the conventional synthesis methods. The characterization experiments showed that the high surface area catalyst exhibits a proper Zr dispersion and strongly bonded nickel active species. The catalyst with a nickel content of 2.5wt% showed a full conversion of NO to N2 in the presence of 10vol% oxygen and 1750ppm of C3H8 in the water vapor-free feed stream at 450°C. Furthermore, N2 yield of the catalyst with a nickel content of 5wt% was found to be 38%, which signifies the capability of the catalyst for NO reduction in the presence of water. Also, hydrothermal and long-term stability study indicated that the catalyst could maintain its structure and performance for a prolonged period without a considerable deactivation. coredata.dc:description: An efficient C3H8–SCR catalyst with remarkable surface acidity, high surface area and high hydrothermal stability has been developed using an innovative catalyst preparation technique. In this method, a combination of direct and post-synthesis methods (DS–PS) has been employed sequentially for the preparation of a highly Zr-loaded SBA-15 (32.1wt%). A series of novel catalysts have been developed by doping various contents of nickel on the prepared Zr-loaded support and have been used for NO reduction with propane in the presence of excess oxygen and water vapor in a fixed bed reactor. Among the various catalysts prepared, the catalyst with a nickel content of 2.5wt% exhibited the highest activity with the ability to fully convert NO into N2 in the presence of 10% oxygen, 1750ppm propane and 500ppm NO at 450°C. A satisfactory catalytic activity has been found in the presence of 7vol% of water vapor.
